Ahh, I believe this is due to measurement discrepancies

We measure in things like centimeters and inches, they are quite large, and one at least is easy to break down

Micro-physics, however, measures in atoms, which are far too small and numerous for us to count properly

So from our perspective we are cubing a fractional number, and therefore have what looks like an impossible equation

But from the theoretical perspective of physics, such equations are handled at the atomic level, with a base measurement so small it barely exists, and therefore don’t run into a shrinking exponential equation

Instead that water droplets surface area and volume are dependent on a comparatively massive number, but at an incredibly small increment to us

ThePoint/TL;DR: with water droplets: spacial dimensions are measured at the atomic level, not with fractions and decimals at eye level

The first thing that us junior scientists need to learn to accept is that when our methods to discover a thing don't jive with the thing that's actually happening or has happened before us, something in our computations has gone wrong and must be fixed. You can't shout at a rock falling and say it's wrong for not going up, and in fact if it DOES go up, you need to figure out why. There are a number of statements and such that have a decided flaw. How so? Well...

Find someone who is mathmetically-inclined and ask them about Square-Cube Law. If they've looked into it, ask them about the creation of giant robots, like a Mobile Suit from Gundam or a Veritech from Macross/Robotech or whatever. The nice ones will discuss it normally. The anal ones will say it's impossible because the Square-Cube Law would make it too heavy to move or operate or the ground to hold it up or some shit like that. I've heard all this before. The problem with those people is that they're assuming some sort of constant in the object or that you can't simply make something stronger and that it's just impossible when they can't really test it, and they're wrong.

The first flaw is that when people design and build something, they can decide on the materials and the construction to overcome physical limitations. We didn't use to fly, but birds do. Now, there are these huge jets that move people across the world. Giant mobile vehicles on legs are possible, just that the construction is difficult, like all new things. Fortunately, the better and more glaring flaw in Square-Cube Law and the people who cling to it so tightly is that they forget the past: Prehistoric Earth. Dinosaurs roamed the land, alive and in all shapes and sizes. They lived, they moved, they acted, and they did so with great gusto. Frankly, the study of dinosaurs would make the easiest template for a giant robot to follow. It's an already-existing giant body that functioned on land. Much like studying why birds work, studying why dinosaurs worked can allow us to create...well...basically, Zoids. It's a start. Humanoids will follow.

Still, this is why knowledge must grow and change. Nothing that already exists can be catalogued as 'impossible'.

I will attempt to dumb down the explanation in the video with this comment because....well I think it might be fun.

There’s 2 basic principles that are being discussed here to try and conclude that raindrops shouldn’t work because maths says so.

1. The first principle he talks about is ΔG, or Gibbs Free Energy, in regards to ΔS, entropy, and ΔT, temperature in kelvin. None of these terms need to be defined for me to describe what he’s talking about. Basically, things in nature tend to occur spontaneously, that is, they occur without needing energy to occur. For instance, Wet metal sitting in the sun will undergo a chemical reaction automatically ➝ rust. This is spontaneous. In regards to the raindrop, he’s stating that nature constructs raindrop size in a way that, mathematically, should require energy to do so. However, nature constructs their size spontaneously which means zero energy is needed.

2. The discussion about the radius of the raindrop and the math variables to determine the size was just a set of proofs for why principle in number 1 should not occur. Forget the graphs and the x variables. All he’s saying is, the amount of energy needed from nature to construct these raindrops a certain size is proportional to the radius cubed. For instance, if we had a rain drop with a radius of 5 millimeters, then the energy to construct its volume can be calculated by doing 5^3. For those who are unsure what this means, it’s 5 x 5 x 5 = 125. Now, anything raised to the 3rd power is giving us volume because 3 dimensions of Space are needed to get a volume. A length, a width, a thickness. For the most part. 3 dimensions means ^3. However, if we take away a dimension, say thickness, then we only raise the radius to the 2nd power. So this will be 5^2, or 5 x 5 = 25. The number decreasing from 125 to 25 makes perfect sense in regards to energy required. Smaller number means smaller size which means smaller energy needed. BUT, this concept gets completely flipped on its head when you consider objects with a radius less than 1, like 0.5 millimeters for instance. According to the physics in regards to energy consumption, the math needed to answer this question is done the exact same way... 0.5^3 would be the volume (3 dimensions) and 0.5^2 would be the surface area only (2 dimensions). Well what happens when you cube and square 0.5?

0.5 x 0.5 x 0.5 = 0.125 :5^3
0.5 x 0.5 = 0.25. :5^2

This is showing just the opposite. The number that corresponds to the energy required to make the 3dimensional object is SMALLER than the energy required to make the 2dimensional object.

To paint an analogy that illustrates this contraction, that’s like a store charging $5 to buy a single candy bar yet also charging $1.25 for 4 of the same candy bar.

To form a droplet out of water molecules you need to give them energy to form the surface. However, once they come together, they'll give you back an amount of energy proportional to the volume. So, if you add the energy you need to put in and subtract the energy you get back, that gives you the total amount of energy for the whole process, i.e. how much you need to supply to make it all happen in the first place. If that ends up being 0 or less,... well,... that means you literally don't need to do anything to make it happen, so it will happen. If it's positive, that means you need to put in energy, i.e. it won't happen automatically.

Surface=x^2
Volume=x^3
(energy needed) = x^2 - x^3

p.s. "x" here is not some arbitrary length, otherwise you could just change the units and the "sweet spot" would change. "x" is a length scaled to the dimensions of the water molecules, i.e. it is unitless.

Mathematically impossible for droplets to join that are already formed, sure. But, water droplets forming are more a case on what state the water is going from and to. Simplistically, for example, if you want to make a small droplet of water even larger, simply have that droplet of water in an environment where it is cooler than the dew point of the local ambient air.
When air is containing H2O, in gaseous state, each molecule of H2O is an individual molecule (stating the obvious.) Fog (or clouds) are several molecules of H2O; not quite what considered a droplet (again, stating the obvious.) If you have a droplet of water that is below this dew point then each surrounding individual H20 molecule that comes into contact with that surface droplet of water easily become a part of it. The surface tension of a droplet of water does not repel an individual H2O molecule. This occurs extremely fast, even though it is one H2O molecule at a time.
This leads an experiment in relative humidity and dew points that anyone can do in their own bathroom; with a shower, a space heater, and a glass of cold water. ;-)

Okay, wait. Just because the volume (or the energy derived from the volume) is less than the surface area (or the energy required by the surface area), that doesn't mean the raindrop will shrink. That would just bring it to a state with even less energy.

Let's say we have a raindrop with radius 0.5. Its surface area is 0.5^2 (yes, I know that's not really the area of a sphere but it doesn't matter) = 0.25. Its volume is 0.5^3 = 0.125. The larger the ratio between the volume and the surface area, the more energy. The ratio here is 0.125/0.25 = 0.5.

Now, if the raindrop was to, say, split into two, the volume of one of the two new raindrops would be half of the original. 0,125/2 = 0.0625. The radius is the cubic root of 0.0625 = 0.397. The surface area is 0.397^2 = 0.157. The new ratio is 0.0625/0.157 = 0.397.

Why would the raindrops split up? It only brings them to a less energetic state. Am I just missing something?

There is something very misleading about saying, "Cubing tends to make things bigger than squaring, but for really small radii, the opposite is true".  This applies to real numbers, in pure math, but it's irrelevant in physics.  A number like 1000 is meaningless in physics.  Real numbers don't mean anything unless they are coefficients of a unit.  Imagine calculating the volume of a cube with 10cm edges.  It's 1000cm³, right?  But now imagine finding the volume of a cube with 0.1m edges.  It's 0.001m³!  How is it possible that the 10cm cube has a volume that's bigger than its edges, but the 0.1m cube has a volume that's smaller than its edges?  Answer:  You can't compare cm to cm³.  They're different units.  Both cubes are exactly the same, and 1000cm³ = 0.001m³.  You should recognize that just by choosing a different unit, you can make any measurement of 0.01 become 10, or vice versa.

The "cubing a small number makes it smaller than squaring it" is a red herring: (1) it is measurement-unit dependent for any given thing and (2) you cannot treat cubes and squares as equivalent. Let's play with a metre:
1 m = 100 cm = 0.001 km
1 m^2 = 10000 cm^2 = 0.000001 km^2
1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3 = 0.000000001 km^3

So, in the terms of this video, if you measure a metre in cm, cubing it "makes it bigger than squaring it"; if you measure it in km, cubing it "makes it smaller than squaring it".

Yet it is the same thing.

In order to make his greater than one, less than one argument work, you have to make the radius or diameter of an equilibrium droplet equal one. A equilibrium droplet is one of a size where the positive change in surface energy with increasing size and the negative change in volume (condensation) energy are equal and opposite.

Therefore, the units are not meters or centimeters, they are whatever that equilibrium size happens to be.

I read some confusion in the comments.  I think, perhaps, the root of the confusion has to do with the sign of the two energies under consideration.  The sign of the energy change of making a volume of liquid water is negative.  We call this condensation, it releases energy.  The sign of the energy change for making more surface area between water and air is positive.  Making more area absorbs energy.  The two processes oppose each other.  This is where the square cube relationship comes in.  What the video does not do is supply the coefficients, that is the numeric values of the energy changes.  The droplet size at which they become equal, beyond which a droplet can grow by unaided condensation is small, but much larger than can be assembled by random collisions of water molecules.  This is where nucleation comes in, but that is not covered in this video.

In order for the process of rain drop formation to occur, an initial condition must place the solution of the equation(s) above what's called a critical threshold. Above the CT means the process will always occur and below the CT means the process will not occur. What he's saying is that due to the natural properties of the water molecule, it is mathematically improbable (virtually impossible) for rain drops to occur purely of water. However, in the Minute Earth video, he explains that a clump of material microscopically small is enough to put the solution above the critical threshold and thus not just allow raindrops to form but FORCE them.

If you have water vapor and a small bit of debris, it WILL form a rain drop. Not probably. It will. That's what critical threshold means. It's a binary always/never operator.

I don't think this explanation is quite true for pure water. Yes in a very small drop the surface energy increases faster than the volume energy, but you have to remember that we are not just talking about 1 surface and one volume. We are essentially talking about the destruction of two smaller droplets to form 1 larger one.

Individual water molecules or very small small clusters of water molecules are in an even higher energy state because they have even fewer bonds per molecule than a small droplet they might join. You move to a lower energy state by teh destruction of those two smaller droplets.

So essentially instead of  the energy change being R^2-R^3 it is  more like (for two equal sized drops) R^2-R^3 - 2((R/2^(1/3))^(2)-(R/2^(1/3))^(3))

Where (R/2^(1/3)) is the radius of a sphere with half the volume.

Since there's a lot of confusion about what the video is trying to say, here's a simplified list of concepts so that you connect everything he's saying:
1) Physical objects want to go towards the lowest energy state they can
2) When forming liquid droplets, there is energy associated with both the volume and surface area of the droplets
3) Because of the way the volume and surface area effect the energy of droplets, a larger droplet will lose energy by GROWING in size, while a smaller droplet will lose energy by SHRINKING in size. Remember that droplets will tend towards whatever loses them energy.
4) The rain you see from the sky is on the smaller side of this scale, and therefore it's "physically impossible" for pure water in clouds to ever condense into raindrops because it means they'd be increasing their energy.
5) Watch the minuteearth video and it will explain that raindrops aren't pure water, but instead form around specks of dirt or other impurities in the air. This allows smaller droplets to grow large enough to become raindrops while still decreasing their energy.

I see a lot of mislead comments and answers. No, units don't matter!

Say the energy you get from the volume is Ev = A.r³, and the energy required for the surface is Es = B.r². A and B are constants expressed in units of energy per cube meter and square meters respectively, for example in J/m³ and J/m².

Using an r' with a different unit than r also involves changing the units of A and B.
When you want to switch to cm for example, you'll get A' = A J/(100cm)³ = Ax10^-6 J/cm³, but B' = B/(100cm)² = Bx10^-4 J/cm² (notice the different power of 10!)

In the video, he implicitly simplifies the problem by having A = 1 J/m³ and B = 1 J/m² so we can compare r^2 and r^3 without thinking about A and B, but they are here nevertheless.
You can't compare/add/subtract two different units anyway.
